list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Sketch the graph of $y=(x−2)2−4∣x−2∣−1$, for $−3≤x≤7$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, solve the equation $(x−2)2−4∣x−2∣−1=0$.
[2]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $y=(x−2)2−4∣x−2∣−1$ for
$−3≤x≤7$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d07f4430-c59c-44f9-a842-b167cf69a868/images/3d5a866f-0959-48f4-941c-c6486f9873ca/0ab2fa40cd74cdb2dd31cab2dedea2512bfb0bd0.svg)




The solutions to the equation $(x−2)2−4∣x−2∣−1=0$ are the
$x$-coordinates of the points C and D.
Hence the solutions to the equation are
$x≈−2.24,6.24​$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=2ex−e−x​$, $x∈R$.

Show that $f$ is an odd function. [2]


Now, consider the function $g$ given by $g(x)=2xx4+2​$ , $x∈R,x=0$.

By considering the graph of $y=f(x)−g(x)$, solve $f(x)>g(x)$ for $x∈R$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(−x)$, we get
$$$f(−x)​=2e−x−e−(−x)​=2e−x−ex​=−2ex−e−x​=−f(x)​$$$
$Therefore, f(x) is an odd function​$


If $f(x)−g(x)>0$, then $f(x)>g(x)$. Using G.D.C., we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cf76b687-c4cf-4f02-a51c-0d0d8c929218/images/0ae01be6-8c62-4dff-b5d4-bdc1c895874f/AA930a.PNG)


We see that $f(x)−g(x)>0$ for $−4.55<x<0$ and $x>4.55$.
Therefore $f(x)>g(x)$ over the intervals
$−4.55<x<0 and x>4.55​$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Let $f(x)=5x−24−ax​$.

Write down the equation of the vertical asymptote of the graph of $y=f(x)$.[1]


The line $y=−1.4$ is a horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y=f(x)$.


Find the value of $a$.[2]



The line $y=x−c$, where $c∈R+$, intersects the graph of $y=​f(x)​$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $c$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Solving the equation $5x−2=0$, we have $x=52​​$


The horizontal asymptote will be equal to $x→±∞lim​f(x)$. We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)−1.4​=x→±∞lim​5x−24−ax​=−5a​a=7​​$$$


If we draw the graph of $y=∣f(x)∣$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/423ecaf7-2110-4ebe-8d00-cb3ef860ab02/aa1027a.PNG)


A line of the form $y=x−c$ where $c∈R+$ has a gradient of $m=1$ and a $y$-intercept that is less than zero. The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x$, which represents an absolute upper limit for the $y$-intercept.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/66fa47d7-6be3-4bd7-bfc8-104af16f2d66/aa1027b.PNG)


The line $y=x$ intersects the graph of $y=​f(x)​$ at three points.
The following diagram shows the graph of $y=x−0.571$, which passes through the point A$(0.571,0)$ and has a $y$-intercept of $−0.571$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d38234a3-2406-4a17-ad72-c2dccf3aebd1/images/47bdebc2-8242-44ff-8e71-2793f3857f00/aa1027c.PNG)


The line $y=x−0.571$ intersects the graph of $y=​f(x)​$ at two points. Any line of gradient $m=1$ and $y$-intercept of less than $−0.571$ will intersect the graph of $y=​f(x)​$ exactly once.
Therefore, $c>0.571​$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=x2arcsin(x)$, for $−1≤x≤1$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$. [3]



Write down the range of $f$. [2]



Solve the inequality $​x2arcsin(x)​>0.5$. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2a496ce7-1c09-468e-9b78-c54c7e72457b/images/a26a65b4-368f-4db1-b1cb-e05ffd8c1af2/116e48b3daf01abd56171298ff9c296be1c29e27.svg)




$[−2π​,2π​]​$


If we solve the equation $∣x2arcsin(x)∣=0.5$ for $x$, we have
$$$x2arcsin(x)x​=±0.5=±0.761[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence we get
$$$−2π​≤x2arcsin(x)−1≤x​<<​−0.5−0.761​ or  or ​0.50.761​<<​x2arcsin(x)≤2π​x≤1​​$$$
Hence the set of solutions
to the inequality $∣x2arcsin(x)∣>0.5$ is
$$$[−1,−0.761)∪(0.761,1]​​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A population of endangered snow leopards, $P$, can be modelled by the
equation
$$$Pt​=P0​ekt,​$$$
where $P0​$ is the initial population,
and $t$ is measured in years.


After one year, it is estimated that $P0​P1​​=0.93$.


Find the value of $k$.


Interpret the meaning of the value of $k$. [3]





Find the least number of whole years for which
$P0​Pt​​<0.50$. [5]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $t=1$ in the equation $Pt​=P0​ekt$, we have
$$$P1​P0​P1​​0.93k​=P0​ek(1)=ek=ek=ln0.93​$$$
$$$k≈−0.0726​$$$


$The rate at which the population of leopards exponentially decrease​$




We have
$$$P0​Pt​​e−0.0726t−0.0726ttt​<0.50<0.50<ln0.50>−0.0726ln0.50​>9.55​$$$
Hence the least number of whole years
for which $P0​Pt​​<0.50$ is
$t=10​$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider the graphs of $y=−21​∣x∣$ and $y=2∣x∣−a$, where
$a∈Z+$.


Sketch the graphs on the same set of axes. [2]



Given that the graphs enclose a region of area 40 square units,
find the value of $a$. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graphs of $y=−21​∣x∣$ and
$y=2∣x∣−a$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e1f7ba47-5c7f-4483-baa8-4c9fa89f8efb/images/52d9876b-801d-4d99-bd5b-65f532bdeb39/68ec0f82b42dd94d75c48aa4929409d0a553c4d8.svg)




The two lines in the $4$th quadrant intersect when
$$$−21​x−x2ax​=2x−a[since x>0]=4x−2a=5x=52a​​$$$
Hence the area enclosed between
the two graphs is
$$$2[21​(base×height)]​=2[21​(a×52a​)]=52a2​​$$$
Hence, given that the area is $40$
square units, we find
$$$52a2​a2​=40=100​$$$
$$$a=10​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Let $f(x)=cx−209−12x​$, for $x=c20​$, where
$c=0$.


The line $x=5$ is a vertical asymptote to the graph of $y=f(x)$.


Find the value of $c$.


Write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote to the graph
of $y=f(x)$.[4]





The line $y=h$, where $h∈R$, intersects the
graph of $y=​f(x)​$ at exactly one point. Find the
possible values of $h$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the equation of the vertical asymptote, we get
$$$5c−205c​=0=0=20c=4​​$$$


$y=−3​$




If we draw the graph of $y=∣f(x)∣$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3658e86-b348-445b-bade-3ea93bdc0f36/images/7c07f0a2-c2b1-440d-be6c-385ece839f36/05e9ba9d7a31d35d6e66b11e5f0ab06197d7db87.svg)


A line of the form $y=h$ can intersect the graph of $y=∣f(x)∣$
exactly at one point either at A or at B, as shown on the diagram
above.
Hence we find
$h=0,3​$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Sketch the curve $y=−​x−25​​$ and line
$y=−x−4$ on the same axes,
clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes.
[3]



Find the exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$.
[5]
list.markScheme:
Let $f(x)=−​x−25​​$ where $x∈R$,
$x=2$.
Since $f(x)<0$ for all $x∈R$, $x=2$, the curve
$y=f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=−​−25​​=−25​​$$$
Hence the point A$(0,−5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)=0$$$
Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=2$. Hence the line $x=2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y=f(x)$.
The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y=−4−x$ are B$(−4,0)$ and
C$(0,−4)$.
If we sketch the curve $y=f(x)$ and line $y=−x−4$ on the same
axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)




If we solve the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x<2$, we
find
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−3(x+3)(x−1)x​=−x−25​[since x−2<0]=−5=−5=0=0=−3,1​$$$
If we simplify the equation
$x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ for $x>2$, we have
$$$x+4(x+4)(x−2)x2+2x−8x2+2x−13​=x−25​[since x−2>0]=5=5=0​$$$
Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find
$$$x​=2−2+22−4(1)(−13)​​[since x>2]=2−2+214​​=−1+14​​$$$
Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $x+4=∣x−2∣5​$ are  $−3,1,−1+14​​$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=1+x+34x​$, for
$x=−3$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes
and
points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4]



Find an expression for $f−1$. [4]



Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x)=f−1(x)$. [3]



Solve the inequality $∣f(x)∣<2$. [4]



Solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$1+x+34x​x+35x+3​5x+3x​=0=0=0=−53​​$$$
Hence the point
P$(−3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we obtain
$$$y​=f(0)=1​$$$
Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→±∞lim​f(x)​=1+14​=5​$$$
Hence the line $y=5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x=−3$. Hence the line
$x=−3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
If we sketch of the graph of $y=f(x)$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)




If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we find
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)​=x=x​$$$
$$$1+y+34y​y+35y+3​5y+3(5−x)yy​=x=x=xy+3x=3x−3=5−x3x−3​​$$$
Hence an expression for
$f−1$ is
$f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​​$


If we solve the equation $f(x)=f−1(x)$ for $x$, we get
$$$f(x)1+x+34x​x+35x+3​(5x+3)(5−x)25x−5x2+15−3x−8x2+16x+24​=f−1(x)=5−x3x−3​=5−x3x−3​=(3x−3)(x+3)=3x2+9x−3x−9=0​$$$
$$$x2−2x−3(x+1)(x−3)​=0=0​$$$
$$$x=−1,3​$$$


We have
$$$−2f−1(−2)​<<​∣f(x)∣f(x)x​<<<​22f−1(2)[since f−1(f(x))=x]​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for $x=−2$,
we get
$$$f−1(−2)​=5−(−2)3(−2)−3​=−79​​$$$
Evaluating $y=f−1(x)$ for
$x=2$, we obtain
$$$f−1(2)​=5−23(2)−3​=1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$∣f(x)∣<2$ is
$−79​<x<1​$


If we solve the inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ for $∣x∣$, we get
$$$1+∣x∣+34∣x∣​∣x∣+34∣x∣​4∣x∣3∣x∣∣x∣​<2<1<∣x∣+3<3<1​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(∣x∣)<2$ is
$−1<x<1​$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Solve the inequality $x2≥2x+3$. [2]



Use mathematical induction to prove that $2n>n2−2$ for all
$n∈Z+$, $n≥3$.[6]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graphs of $y=x2$ and $y=2x+3$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2657c2a5-86af-44db-8be4-bfd4d027e790/images/2ce2fde1-d607-4fa0-9109-01ca871a4538/8559be520206e999f46f83d313584ee1a94282b7.svg)


Using the $x$-coordinates of A and B, we see that the graph of
$y=x2$ is above the graph of $y=2x+3$ when $x<−1$ and
$x>3$, and the graphs intersect at $x=−1,3$.
Hence the solution set to the inequality $x2≥2x+3$ is
$(−∞,−1]∪[3,∞)​$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$2n​>n2−2[for n≥3]​$$$


Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$, $n≥3$.
Base case. For $n=3$, we have
$$$23=8​>32−2=7​$$$
Hence P$(3)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥3$. In other words, we assume that
$$$2k​>k2−2(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥3$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$2k+1​>(k+1)2−2(1)​$$$
From the
left hand side of the inequality $(1)$, we obtain
$$$2k+1[by part (a)]​=2⋅2k>2[k2−2][by (IH)]=k2+[k2−4]≥2k+3+[k2−4]=[k2+2k+1]−2=(k+1)2−2​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(3)$ holds, and for every $k≥3$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $n∈Z+,n≥3$.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Let
$f(x)=x4−0.4x3−2.85x2+0.9x+1.35$,
for $x∈R$.


Find the solutions for $f(x)>0$. [3]



For the graph of $y=f(x)$,


find the coordinates of local minimum and maximum points.


find the $x$-coordinates of the points of inflexion. [5]





The domain of $f$ is now restricted to $[a,b]$ where
$a,b∈R+$.




Write down the smallest value of $a>0$ and the largest value
of $b>0$ for which $f$ has an inverse. Give your answers
correct to three significant figures.


For these values of $a$ and $b$, sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$
and $y=f−1(x)$ on the same set of axes, showing clearly the
coordinates of the end points of each curve.


Solve $f−1(x)=0.5$. [6]





Let $g(x)=32​sin(2x−1)+21​$,
$21​−4π​≤x≤21​+4π​$.




Find an expression for $g−1$ and state its domain.


Solve $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$. [8]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/44e18fcd-818c-481b-aabd-bbc35f210168/245a2a1979fce06233cc54e60878b1e96f11b9d1.svg)


From the diagram, we see that $f$ is positive on the intervals
$(−∞,−1.5)$, $(−0.6,1)$ and $(1.5,∞)$, and negative on
$(−1.5,−0.6)$ and $(1,1.5)$.
Hence the set of solutions to the inequality $f(x)>0$ is
$$$(−∞,−1.5)∪(−0.6,1)∪(1.5,∞)​​$$$




From the diagram, we see that the graph of $y=f(x)$ has a
local
maximum at point A and local minimums at points B and C.
Hence the coordinates of the local max and min points are
$$$local max:local min:​(0.155,1.42)​(−1.13,−1.10)​ and (1.28,−0.322)​​$$$


We have
$$$f(x)f′(x)f′′(x)​=x4−0.4x3−2.85x2+0.9x+1.35=4x3−1.2x2−5.7x+0.9=12x2−2.4x−5.7​$$$
Hence, if we solve the equation
$f′′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$12x2−2.4x−5.7​=0​$$$
$$$x≈−0.596,0.796​[by using G.D.C.]$$$






From the diagram, we see that $f$ is a bijection if its domain
is restricted to $[−1.13,0.155]$ or $[0.155,1.28]$.
As it is given that $a,b>0$, hence $f$ has an inverse if
$a=0.155​$
and  $b=1.28​$


The graph of $y=f−1(x)$ is the reflection of the graph of
$y=f(x)$ across the line $y=x$.
Hence, if we sketch the graphs of $y=f(x)$ and $y=f−1(x)$
on the same set of axes, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b276ac45-671f-4c75-9dea-a3774fc53f67/images/3ebbda78-45c5-40ce-9d82-70daf75779a2/524a320d1d2563d4a110444319e1f709eb5ee6c6.svg)




If we solve the equation $f−1(x)=0.5$ for $x$, we obtain
$$$f(f−1(x))​=f(0.5)​$$$
$$$x=1.1​[since f(f−1(x))=x]$$$






Solving the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)32​sin(2y−1)+21​32​sin(2y−1)sin(2y−1)2y−1y​=x=x=x=22x−1​=46x−3​=arcsin(46x−3​)=21​arcsin(46x−3​)+21​​$$$
Hence an expression for $g−1$ is
$g−1(x)=21​arcsin(46x−3​)+21​​$
The range of $g$ is
$$$[−32​+21​,32​+21​]=[−61​,67​]​$$$
Hence the domain of $g−1$ is
$[−61​,67​]​$


Solving the inequality $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$ for $x$, we
get
$$$f−1(g(x))g(x)g(x)xx​<0.5>f(0.5)[since f is decreasing]>1.1>g−1(1.1)[since g−1 is increasing]>1.06​$$$
Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $(f−1∘g)(x)<0.5$ is
$$$(1.06,21​+4π​]​​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Consider the function defined by $f(x)=(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x$ for
$x∈R$, $x>p$.


Find the value of $p$. [2]



Find an expression for $f′(x)$. [3]



The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of
inflexion.

Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or
concave up over its domain. [3]


The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3ln(x+31​)+x$,
for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.


Find an expression for $g′(x)$. [4]



Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of
$g′(x)$.[2]



Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3]



Solve $f(x)<g(x)$ for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.[5]
list.markScheme:
Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$p=−3​$


Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x]=x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1​​$$$


Differentiating $f′$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′′(x)​=dxd​[x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1]=(x+3)2(x+3)(2)−(2x−6)​+x+32​=(x+3)22x+18​​$$$
Hence, over $x>−3$, we have $f′′(x)>0$. Therefore,
$f is concave up​$


Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$g′(x)​=dxd​[3ln(x+31​)+x]=3(x+3)(−(x+3)21​)+1=x+3−3​+1=x+3x​​​$$$


The denominator of $g′$ is zero when $x=−3$.
Hence,
$the line x=−3 is a vertical asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $∞$, we have
$$$x→∞lim​g′(x)​=x→∞lim​x+3x​=x→∞lim​1+x3​1​=1​$$$
Hence,
$the line y=1 is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$


From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is
$$$g′′(x)​=dxd​[x+3x​]=(x+3)23​​$$$
Hence, $g′′(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is
$$$g(0)​=3ln(31​)+0=−3ln(3)​​$$$


Using logarithm properties, we get
$$$f(x)(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x(2x−6)ln(x+3)(2x−3)ln(x+3)​<g(x)<3ln(x+31​)+x<−3ln(x+3)<0​$$$
Thus, we have two options
$$$[2x−3<0&ln(x+3)>0][x<1.5&ln(x+3)>0]x<1.5−2<​ or [2x−3>0&ln(x+3)<0] or [x>1.5&ln(x+3)<0]&1<x+3[since ln(x+3)>0 for x>1.5]x<1.5​$$$
Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $−2<x<1.5​$
